content.webTitle: Sarah Hunter crowned women’s player of the year by World Rugby

fields.headline: Sarah Hunter crowned women’s player of the year by World Rugby
fields.bodyText: England’s women’s captain, Sarah Hunter, has been crowned World Rugby’s female player of 2016, with New Zealand’s Beauden Barrett winning the men’s award. The England forward Maro Itoje was named the breakthrough player while the All Blacks’ Steve Hansen was voted the coach of the year for the fourth time in five years. Hunter, who led England to a 12-10 victory over Ireland on Sunday, has been a stabilising figure at No8 for her country with many of her team-mates away on the sevens circuit. Barrett has added a new dimension to New Zealand’s attacking game since taking over as first-choice fly-half, collecting the award ahead of three English contenders – Billy Vunipola, Owen Farrell and Itoje – plus fellow Kiwi Dane Coles and Ireland’s Jamie Heaslip. It is the fifth year in a row an All Black player has lifted the top prize, with Dan Carter, Kieran Read and Brodie Retallick all recent winners. Hansen took the coaching accolade ahead of England’s Eddie Jones and Fiji’s Olympic gold medal-winning sevens coach Ben Ryan, with New Zealand also voted team of the year. Ireland’s Syd Millar received the Vernon Pugh award for distinguished service. England have named a virtually unchanged squad of 33 for Saturday’s game against Fiji, with only Sale’s Josh Beaumont not reporting back to Bagshot training. World Rugby award winners Men’s Player of the Year Beauden Barrett (New Zealand) Women’s Player of the Year Sarah Hunter (England) Team of the Year New Zealand Coach of the Year Steve Hansen (New Zealand) Breakthrough Player of the Year Maro Itoje (England) Men’s Sevens Player of the Year Seabelo Senatla, South Africa Women’s Sevens Player of the Year Charlotte Caslick (Australia) Referee Award Alhambra Nievas (Spain) and Rasta Rasivhenge (South Africa) Vernon Pugh Award for Distinguished Service Syd Millar Award for Character Rugby Opens Borders (Austrian Rugby Union) IRPA Special Merit Award Jean de Villiers (South Africa)
